Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I sat at my kitchen table, headset on, laptop open, scripts ready. My shift as a telemarketer had just begun when my grandson, Ethan, wandered in, his face clouded with uncertainty. “Grandpa, how do you know when you’re ready for something new?” he asked, voice barely above a whisper. My heart ached to pause everything, to give him the thoughtful answer he deserved, to share the lessons I’d gathered over decades. But just then, my screen flashed—an incoming call. I clicked accept, and a customer’s angry voice filled my ear, demanding to know why our offer was worth their time, challenging every word I said. My training told me to stay calm, to answer with patience and clarity, to keep the customer on the line. Yet, Ethan lingered, eyes searching mine for guidance. I felt torn, pulled between the duty to my job and the responsibility to my family. My mind raced, caught between the script in my ear and the wisdom in my heart, unsure which voice to answer first.
